title: Understanding Enthalpy Change
text: The standard enthalpy change for a reaction, ΔH°, can be calculated using the equation: ΔH° $$=$$ ΣΔH_f°(products) - ΣΔH_f°(reactants).

title: Molar Enthalpy of Formation
text: Remember that the standard enthalpy of formation, ΔH_f°, is the change in enthalpy when one mole of a compound is formed from its elements in their standard state. Values for O₂ is $$0$$ $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$ because it's an element in its standard state.

title: Stoichiometry Considerations
text: Pay attention to the stoichiometric coefficients in the balanced reaction. They affect how you calculate the total enthalpy change for the substances involved.

title: Calculate ΔH° for Products
text: Find the sum of the standard enthalpies of formation for the products using stoichiometric coefficients: ΔH°(products) $$=$$ ΔH_f°(CO₂) + 2*ΔH_f°(H₂O).

title: Calculate ΔH° for Reactants
text: Calculate the sum of the standard enthalpies of formation for the reactants: ΔH°(reactants) $$=$$ ΔH_f°(CH₄) + 2*ΔH_f°(O₂).

title: Final Calculation for ΔH°
text: Subtract the sum of the enthalpies of the reactants from the sum of the enthalpies of the products to find ΔH° of the reaction: ΔH° $$=$$ [ΔH°(products)] - [ΔH°(reactants)].
